#Text=Wikinews interviews Israeli mathematician and writer Aner Shalev
#Text=Wednesday , September 19 , 2007
#Text=Aner Shalev is an Israeli mathematician and writer born in 1958 in Kibbutz Kinneret , Tiberias .
#Text=Currently Shalev is a Professor at Hebrew University of Jerusalem 's Einstein Institute of Mathematics .
#Text=At the moment Shalev is in Levico Terme , Trento , Italy for a conference .
#Text=He was interviewed by Wikinews .
#Text=Interview
#Text=Aner Shalev
#Text=What are you going to talk about here in Levico ?
#Text=I called it Character , walks and words .
#Text=There is a whole topic which is called asymptotic groups theory .
#Text=There are groups which express the symmetry of some structures .
#Text=Studying groups is a bit like studying symmetry .
#Text=It 's very beautiful I think .
#Text=And then when you do it in an asymptotic way is like you do n't look at the small details .
#Text=It 's like from the sky .
#Text=You look at the general patterns .
#Text=And there is another topic which is very important in mathematics which is called representation theory .
#Text=So I will mainly talk about how to use a representation theory to solve all kind of problems and conjectures in asymptotic groups theory .
#Text=Why did you choose to study mathematics ?
#Text=First of all because it was beautiful .
#Text=When I was ten my father already showed me some stuff in mathematics and the beauty and the imagination was quite apparent .
#Text=I also like the freedom in mathematics .
#Text=If you study physics or chemistry then you should describe the real world .
#Text=But in mathematics you can build your own structures .
#Text=You can walk in worlds created by the imagination of people .
#Text=You 're not committed to the real world .
#Text=It 's almost like God to some extent .
#Text=You can create worlds , you can study them .
#Text=I think it 's a combination of the beauty , of the imagination , of the freedom .
#Text=Many people , and many students , dislike math .
#Text=Why do you think it is so ?
#Text=First of all I think maybe they have bad teachers , which is a problem .
#Text=You have to have very good teachers in mathematics if you really want to enjoy and to succeed in it .
#Text=Probably some people mainly think about the scientific part of it – you have to be accurate - and they see less these elements of the freedom , and the imagination , and creation .
#Text=Maybe they do n't like the precise nature of mathematics .

#Text=Also when I talk mathematics I notice the language is very important in mathematics and I actually notice that many times people fail in mathematics because they do n't know how to write a composition .
#Text=They have ideas but they can not formulate them in the right way .

#Text=Actually I find many connections between mathematics and literature because almost all the thing I told about mathematics are also seen in literature and in writing because when you write you can describe the real world , but you can also create worlds of fiction .
#Text=So you have imagination , you have total freedom , you can invent characters , you can invent all kind of development and surprises and this kind of end of story or another .
#Text=Also the language is important in writing and in literature .
#Text=So in a way people often do n't know how to combine the two fields .
#Text=It could look like almost the opposite : literature is kind of arts and mathematics is science but they also see a lot in common and there where mathematician who were writers .
#Text=For example the most famous is Lewis Carrol , author of Alice in Wonderland .
#Text=You 're not only a mathematician .
#Text=You also wrote two collections of short stories and a novel .
#Text=Why did you begin to write ?
#Text=When I was quite young I was interested in psychoanalysis and in dreams .
#Text=I was trying to interpret my dreams .
#Text=I started to write down my dreams .
#Text=And then I noticed that I cheat a little bit when I write them down .
#Text=Sometimes I make them more pretty then they were actually .

#Text=So instead of documenting the dreams it gradually became also like adding creational elements , and I think that somehow through writing my dreams I gradually came to writing , also poems , but mainly stories .

#Text=I 'm a little bit inspired by dreams but when eventually I started to write more seriously I was more interested in structure which also .. a bit like mathematics in a way .. for example my first book is called Opus 1 .. a collection of four long stories with musical structures .
#Text=The first part is called Legato and the second part was called Staccato .
#Text=In the legato part the sentences are very long and without breaks almost like stream of consciousness .
#Text=In the staccato part it 's like a music : a lot of break , very very short sentences .
#Text=It was a bit experimenting connections between the language and the music and the psychology of people .
#Text=In the second book I made another experiment .
#Text=It 's a book of opening , Overtures I called it , and there is no end to the stories .
#Text=There are seventy beginning of stories without ends .
#Text=In the novel Dark Matters I think what interested me in the structure was two thing : simple narrative and email .
#Text=It keeps changing between narrative and email .
#Text=Another thing was two different time scapes : one goes very slow and one goes very fast and they almost kind of meet in the end .
#Text=It 's a little bit like Achilles and the turtle .
#Text=... love story and romance and surprises and tragedies and all this but also this structure interested me a lot .
#Text=Why did you choose this particular structure ?
#Text=When I tell stories I do n't like that everything will be clear from the beginning .
#Text=I like that something will be a bit of secret , or even unreliable narrator : someone tells something and first you trust him but then you read more and you become thrilled by everything .

#Text=I think by using emails on the one hand which are more the voice of the woman Eva and narrative which is more the perspective of the man Adam , I kind of confront them , their different perspective and then kind somehow you can see the distortions in the way the story is told .
#Text=I think that in this kind of structure there is a very gradual clarification of the relationship and the forth going on .

#Text=By : Clive Anderson On September 1 , 2015 More than 300,000 people , not just Muslims , have gone missing in the world of cyclones since Monday night ’s huge National Day of Prayer , a major event commemorating the year when the world held its first blood , and bringing about a profound junta of peace in the Middle East .
